Description: Fragmentary ring oil-lamp with brindged nozzle (broken). Wheel-made body with a large central tube. Inward-sloping walls with an everted rim. The applied nozzle is short and rounded. Micaceous Nile silt clay with numerous lime inclusions.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Egyptian copy of types found at Athens (Howland 1958, see types 9 and 11), Rhodes (one from a grave, another from domestic structure), Megara Hyblaea and Chios, from contexts dated to between 625BC and 570BC (Bailey 1975, 94). Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals. Princeton.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KC.14) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4829 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
